summary: This document is a chain of internal FBI emails from July 23-24, 2019, discussing an incident where Jeffrey Epstein was found unconscious in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) with red marks on his neck. The emails detail the initial report, the response from staff, the denial of involvement by his cellmate, and the initiation of an investigation, while also noting media inquiry from the Washington Post.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the emails; found unconscious in his cell at MCC with red marks on his neck, revived but with no memory of the event.

persons.name: SSA
persons.context: FBI Special Agent in New York receiving and forwarding updates about the Epstein incident, coordinating the submission of a Significant Case Notification (SCN).

persons.name: Assistant Director in Charge
persons.context: Head of the FBI New York Office who was notified of the incident involving Epstein in custody.

connections.description: SSA is receiving and reporting on the incident involving Epstein in custody, indicating an investigative oversight role.
The Assistant Director was informed of the incident, showing Epstein's case was under high-level FBI scrutiny.

events.title: Epstein Found Unconscious in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unconscious in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) with red marks on his neck. He was revived by staff but could not recall what happened. His cellmate denied involvement.

events.title: FBI Internal Notification and Media Inquiry
events.description: Internal FBI emails circulate details of the incident, planning to submit a Significant Case Notification (SCN). The Washington Post makes an inquiry to the SDNY about the event.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found unconscious in his MCC cell with red marks on his neck on the night of July 23, 2019.
After being revived by staff, Epstein had no memory of the incident, and his cellmate denied any knowledge or involvement.
The Metropolitan Correctional Center initiated an investigation following standard operating procedures (SOPs).
The Washington Post had already contacted the SDNY for information about the incident, indicating immediate media attention.
The FBI New York Office was actively coordinating internal notifications and updates regarding the incident, highlighting its high-profile nature.
